head.title: Drug Companies And the Public Good

hedline.hl1: Drug Companies And the Public Good

abstract.p: Barry R Bloom letter finds July 23 front-page article exposed shameful conspiracy to prop up drug prices

block.p: ''How Companies Stall Generics and Keep Themselves Healthy'' (front page, July 23) exposed a shameful conspiracy to prop up drug prices. If only the drug companies were directed to conspire for the public good.

Beyond AIDS, more than 300 million people suffer from malaria each year, and a million die; eight million people suffer from tuberculosis. But since these people live mostly in developing countries, they don't represent sufficient markets for companies to recover drug research investments.

''How Companies Stall Generics and Keep Themselves Healthy'' (front page, July 23) exposed a shameful conspiracy to prop up drug prices. If only the drug companies were directed to conspire for the public good.

Beyond AIDS, more than 300 million people suffer from malaria each year, and a million die; eight million people suffer from tuberculosis. But since these people live mostly in developing countries, they don't represent sufficient markets for companies to recover drug research investments.

Industry lawyers could make a compelling case for antitrust waivers for collaboration on drugs and vaccines for devastating diseases. As a precedent, in World War II companies were permitted to collaborate, dramatically accelerating production of penicillin.
The writer is dean of the Harvard School of Public Health.
